Hooker]] | manager = North Star Port Authority | owner = North Star Port Authority | number_of_stores = '''10''' | number_of_anchors = '''4''' | floor_area = {{convert|1500000|sqft|m2|1}} | floors = 2 | website = }} '''Cincinnati Mall''' (formerly '''Cincinnati Mills''' and '''Forest Fair Mall''') is a [[shopping mall]] in the northern suburbs of [[Cincinnati, Ohio]], [[United States]], at the junction of [[Interstate 275 (Ohio)|Interstate 275]] and Gilmore Road (Exit 39). Currently, Cincinnati Mall is a two-story enclosed mall comprising more than than 40 stores and services, as well as a food court and a movie theater; [[anchor store]]s include [[Bass Pro Shops]], [[Burlington Coat Factory]], Danbarry Dollar Saver Cinemas, [[Kohl's]], and Metropolis Nightclub.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.millscorp.com/static/doc_CINCINNATI_LDETAIL.jsp |title=Simon Property Group |publisher=Millscorp.com |date=2007-03-29 |accessdate=2009-07-15}}</ref>
Developed by [[Australia]]-based real estate franchise [[L. J. Hooker]], the mall opened as '''Forest Fair Mall''' in phases between 1988 and 1989. At first, it featured three upscale [[department store]] chains which had not previously operated in the Cincinnati area: [[Parisian (department store chain)|Parisian]], [[B. Altman]], and [[Bonwit Teller]]. By 1990, the latter two declared bankruptcy and closed. Hooker sold the mall in 1991, and it passed through several changes in ownership and anchor tenants; by the late 1990s, Forest Fair Mall was a [[dead mall]], with fewer than thirty-five inline tenants remaining.
[[Maryland]]-based management firm [[Mills Corporation]] purchased the mall in 2002, forcing out the few remaining non-anchor tenants before closing off the entire mall for renovations. In 2004, the property was re-opened as Cincinnati Mills, a discount-oriented mall. North Star Realty of Georgia purchased the mall in 2009.<ref name="Fairfield-Echo">{{cite news|last=Pitman |first=Michael D. |url=http://www.fairfield-echo.com/news/content/oh/story/news/local/2009/01/02/fe010809millssold.html |title=Cincinnati Mills sold â again |publisher=Fairfield-echo.com |date=2009-01-02 |accessdate=2009-07-15}}</ref>
==History== ===Beginnings=== Developer George Herscu, head of the Australian-based real estate firm L. J. Hooker, first proposed to build a mall in Cincinnati, Ohio in the mid-1980s.<ref name="bizjournals">{{cite news|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/dayton/stories/1997/02/24/focus1.html |title=Hooker failure didn't doom its top executives - Dayton Business Journal: |publisher=Bizjournals.com |date=1997-02-21 |accessdate=2009-07-15 |first=Steve |last=Lewis}}</ref> Originally, his mall plans called for [[discount department store]]s such as [[TJ Maxx]] and [[Marshalls]]; these plans were later changed to include primarily upscale merchants. Three high-end department store chainsâ[[B. Altman]], [[Bonwit Teller]], and [[Sakowitz]], only one of which had ever operated in Ohio beforeâwere proposed as anchor stores. The three chains were uninterested, so in 1987, Herscu bought controlling interest in the three chains.<ref name="timeline">{{cite news|url=http://www.enquirer.com/editions/1999/08/15/fin_forest_fair_mall2.html |title=Forest Fair Mall chronology |publisher=Enquirer.com |date= |accessdate=2009-07-15}}</ref> In addition to these three department stores, discount retailer [[bigg's]] and [[Elder-Beerman]], a mid-range department store, were signed on as anchors.
Construction began on Forest Fair Mall in 1986. The east wing opened in July 1988, but due to leasing complications, the rest of the mall did not open until March of the next year.<ref name="timeline"/> The mall featured an ornate design, including skylights, arched copper roofs, and a spacious center court. Entertainment venues at the mall comprised a [[movie theater]], and an indoor [[amusement park]] called Time Out on the Court, which included a [[ferris wheel]] and indoor carousel.
===Downfall=== Despite a strong start, the mall started to falter less than a year after opening. In September 1989, L.J. Hooker filed for [[Chapter 11 bankruptcy]] protection. The B. Altman, Bonwit Teller, and Sakowitz chains proved to be too upscale for the market, and by 1990 all three had closed at the mall, B. Altman and Sakowitz also closing all other stores.<ref name="timeline"/> In January 1991, Hooker sold the mall to seven lenders, who then formed a partnership called FFM Limited Partnership, which hired veterans of the retail industry to run Forest Fair Mall.<ref name="icsc">[http://www.icsc.org/srch/sct/current/sct1000/03a.html ]{{dead link|date=July 2009}}</ref> At the time, the mall was nearly half vacant, and attracting new tenants proved difficult. Nearby centers, most notably [[Tri-County Mall]], were expanding and adding new tenants, thus cutting further into Forest Fair's market.
A "Malls at Forest Fair" concept was introduced in 1992. This concept divided the mall into four retail themes: fashion, lifestyle, and value. An $8 million expansion was completed in August 1993, adding an entertainment complex called Festival at Forest Fair in the former Bonwit Teller space. This new section featured nightclubs and entertainment venues, and featured green slate tiles from [[India]] to invoke an "outdoor experience".<ref>http://www.southlandstone.com/docs/9-Forest_Fair_Mall_1_.pdf</ref><ref>http://www.southlandstone.com/docs/9-Forest_Fair_Mall_2_.pdf</ref> [[Kohl's]] replaced the former B. Altman in September 1994, helping to bring the mall's occupancy up over 75%.<ref name="timeline"/>
===Mid-1990s: Change to a discount mall=== Despite the increase in occupancy brought on by the opening of Kohl's, Forest Fair Mall was sold in 1995. Gator Forest Park Partners, Ltd., of Miami bought the mall in 1996, pledging to invest $10 million in improvements by 1999.<ref name="timeline"/> Glimcher Properties Trust acted as a leasing agent,<ref name="icsc2">{{cite news|url=http://www.icsc.org/srch/sct/sct0103/page1c.php |title=Shopping Centers Today |publisher=Icsc.org |date= |accessdate=2009-07-15}}</ref> helped shift the mall's focus to primarily discount-oriented tenants.<ref name="Post Paeth">{{cite news|url=http://www.cincypost.com/2002/jul/24/forest072402.html|title=Forest Fair sold again|author=Greg Paeth|first=Greg|last=Paeth|work=[[The Cincinnati Post]]|publisher=[[E. W. Scripps Company]]|date=2002-07-24|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20051202115617/http://www.cincypost.com/2002/jul/24/forest072402.html|archivedate=2005-12-02}}</ref>
[[Berean Christian Stores]] was signed on as a junior anchor in October 1997. Parisian closed in 1998, with [[Bass Pro Shops]] taking its place within a year. The [[CompUSA]] store announced in May 1998 that it would move its store in Forest Fair to a new development in Tri-County called Tri-County Marketplace.<ref name="bizjournalcompusa">{{cite news|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/cincinnati/stories/1998/05/25/daily17.html |title=CompUSA leaving Forest Fair Mall for Tri-County area |publisher=Bizjournals.com |date=1998-05-29 |accessdate=2009-07-15}}</ref> Several [[big box]] tenants were also added to Forest Fair Mall's roster over the next two years, including [[Guitar Center]] (which took the vacated CompUSA space), [[Burlington Coat Factory]], [[Off 5th]] and [[Media Play]].<ref name="timeline"/> Time Out closed and cleared out for theaters but was functionally replaced with a smaller family entertainment center called Namco Wonderpark.
===Conversion to Cincinnati Mills=== Despite the addition of several larger-format stores, the mall had seen many of its inline tenants close. In 2002, less than 50 stores remained open;<ref name="Niche">{{cite news|url=http://news.enquirer.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20060712/BIZ01/607120321|title=Mall struggles to find niche|last=Boyer|first=Mike|work=Cincinnati Enquirer|accessdate=2009-01-03}}</ref> that year The Mills Corporation purchased the property for $64 million, and further renovations were put on hold. Mills forced out all of the remaining tenants except for the anchor stores and theaters, and the concourses were closed off. Elder-Beerman also closed at this point; the top floor later became home to Johnny's Toys,<ref name="johnnystoysenq">{{cite news|url=http://www.enquirer.com/editions/2004/08/13/biz_Johnnys13.html |title=Johnny's Toys opens in Cincinnati Mills |publisher=Enquirer.com |date= |accessdate=2009-07-15}}</ref> which was later replaced with [[Steve & Barry's]] (which had re-located from the spot later occupied by Urban Behavior).
After a $70 million renovation by the Mills Corporation, the former Forest Fair Mall reopened on August 19, 2004 as Cincinnati Mills. Media Play closed in 2005, and has been vacant since. In April 2007, the entire Mills portfolio was acquired by Simon Property Group of [[Indianapolis, Indiana]].<ref name="2006biz">{{cite news|url=http://cincinnati.bizjournals.com/cincinnati/stories/2006/05/01/story5.html |title=Despite success, Cincinnati Mills may return to sale rack - Business Courier of Cincinnati: |publisher=Cincinnati.bizjournals.com |date=2006-04-28 |accessdate=2009-07-15}}</ref> Cincinnati Mills suddenly started to decline again, just like its former incarnation: Wonderpark closed in March 2008<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.wcpo.com/news/local/story.aspx?content_id=9997baf8-d912-4d63-8f62-7b5769fdc519 |title=Parents Want Refunds After Wonderpark Closes |publisher=Wcpo.com |date=2008-03-03 |accessdate=2009-07-15}}</ref> after word broke out the manager was paying employees and others to make sex videos.<ref>http://www.wcpo.com/news/local/story/Man-Accused-of-Paying-Minors-To-Make-Sex-Videos/cp23G_BdHUmIy3kSkQkNww.cspx</ref> Bigg's, the largest and oldest tenant in the mall closed next by the end of June.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/cincinnati/stories/2008/05/12/daily32.html |title=Bigg's shuttering Cincinnati Mills store |publisher=Bizjournals.com |date=2008-05-14 |accessdate=2009-07-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://seekingalpha.com/article/87498-simon-property-group-inc-q2-2008-earnings-call-transcript?page=7 |title=Simon Property Group, Inc. Q2 2008 Earnings Call Transcript - Seeking Alpha |quote=Simon Property Group's CEO David Simon said in a July 28, 2008 conference call, "Cincinnati Mills is an asset I donât think over the long run we will be an owner. Weâve made that decision that itâs just not, it produces little [[net operating income|NOI]]. Itâs a lot of work and we just donât view that as being in the long run portfolio of the Mills."}}</ref> Then Simon finally sold the 40% vacant mall to North Star Port Authority. By now, [[Steve and Barry's]] had closed too.<ref>[http://news.cincinnati.com/article/20090102/BIZ01/301020066M ]{{dead link|date=July 2009}}</ref>
On March 4, 2009, the owners of the mall notified tenants that the Mills name did not confer with the transfer of the property, and the shopping center is to be known as "Cincinnati Mall."
In March 2010, the shopping center changed hands again. By this time, the Showcase Cinemas was on its way out, with Off 5th having been gone to an outlet mall. In January 2011, a plan was unveiled to have a new ice rink, [[Candlewood Suites]], entertainment, and dining.<ref>http://news.cincinnati.com/article/AB/20110117/BIZ01/301170023/Cincinnati-Mall-announces-redevelopment</ref>. There will also be an agricultural museum and an indoor bike-mountain range.<ref>http://news.cincinnati.com/article/20110127/BIZ01/301270104/Ambitious-plans-for-Cincinnati-Mall</ref>. ==References== {{Reflist}}
